You feel like the Jets might show up to order a burger before the their rumble with the Sharks.

Like any respectable diner joint they have burgers, fries, shakes and soda. They've even modernized a little with churros and salmon burgers. They actually do have salads, but lets be honest no one goes to Whiz Burgers for a salad, you go to Whiz Burger because you wanted a drippy saucy beef burger with heart-clogging mayonnaise, and salty french fries that leave you full and maybe a little disgusted by yourself.

yups
author: david h.

description:
(Pub Commute Stop 1b)

Making your place all retro and yellow is always a good call.  I bike down 18th St every night, so when we needed an impromptu food stop roughly on the way from 16th/Bryant to 19th/Folsom, naturally the memorably-decored Whiz pops into my head first.

Actually, Whiz makes a pretty good alternative to In-N-Out if you can't be bothered to trek to the wharf or Daly City, or if you just want some beef alternatives (big thumbs up on the turkey burger, btw).  In fact, the fries are even better than In-N-Out.  Note that this is a burger *stand*--you order at a window and eat outside (there's 2 picnic tables and a counter), so mind the weather.

The food and style of the place would definitely merit 5 stars, but I have a couple objections:

1) A place like this is just begging to be open all night.  Sure it's set back a bit from the Mission scene, but not by much, and I'm sure it could be a midnight mecca for hungry hungry hipsters.  But alas, it closes at like 9:45.

2) What's with the surly owner?  Read Ben P's tragicomic review--it doesn't surprise me in the least.

Ok, so now we've picked up Ed M.  On to Homestead!
author: Wes M.

description:
Coolest burger joint in the city
...ok 
Coolest looking burger joint in the city.  

We should pool our money together and buy it cause with the right menu and chef it would be a slam dunk.  The folks that operate it clearly dont know what they have and it shows from the crappy burgers to the dirty ketchup stand out side.  Maybe I will go back and try it but there are other burgers out there to be eaten still..  

Thumbs UP:  Looks like a burger stand from the fifties - not like one of those dorky "diner" style joints but like something from the golden age of Los Angeles. 
Thumbs DOWN:  Please  sell the operation to someone who knows what they are doing
author: Jeff C.

description:
Tried the veggie burger, seasoned fries, and a chocolate malt shake.  Friend got the same, but a banana shake.  Everything was pretty bland.  I appreciated that the veggie burger was not a boca/gardenburger patty.  Not sure if they make it themselves, but it was refreshing to get the vegetarian option at a place like this and have it not be something I could get in the grocery store and reheat myself.  

If you count salt as seasoning, then the seasoned fries were seasoned.  Not quite what I expected from a food item under that moniker.  The chocolate malt shake was solid, but if I'm gonna gulp a milkshake, I kinda want to be wowed.  The banana shake tasted like banana powder yet had chunks of banana in it.  I'm... not sure how I feel about that, honestly.

If this place were open late and I were prone to staggering between dive bars, I might end an evening here, but it's not and I'm not, so I probably will look elsewhere next time I'm in the mood for diner/fast food.
author: elizabeth o.

description:
After a full day of cleaning a storage room, buying a Christmas tree and doing good deeds like donating items to the Goodwill, I needed a burger. Seriously, I thought, "I need a burger." 

I ordered a double bacon (I know!) cheese burger with garlic fries. The burger I had was actually very good. I had no clue what to expect. The quality of meat was surprising, and the cheese wasn't processed American slices. I'm suspicious it was like nacho cheese. It actually tasted really good! The garlic fries were good as well, after of course, I added some seasoning. The garlic fries got the garlic part down. So well, my car filled with the smell of garlic almost instantly. I bet if they sprinkled the fries with some salt or their seasoning would have made them fantastic. 

I really enjoyed Whiz Burger. I can't wait to return! Thank gawd I live 5 minutes away!
author: Michael M.

description:
Been hankerin' for a burger for days now and I worked out really hard this morning so I could get one without feeling all guilty...I still felt a little guilty, but it was good!
This place is absolutely no frills, good cheap food. Friendly guys at the window, fast service, yummy burgers.  Your not going to get blue cheese and kobe beef but you'll love the juicy fatty goodness.  This place has plenty of character and that makes up for its lack of...dare I say, class!
author: Nilu r.

description:
I've driven by this seemingly forsaken Mission institution for decades and not tried their burger since my earliest drive by's back then.  One of my favorite cab divers suggested Whiz after one of my recent Yelp reviews and here I am.  A prime corner at South Van Ness and 18th with parking aplenty and an equal amount of not giving a shit attitude.  Across the street from a pristine Church but somehow it feels like a blighted neighborhood and I get the feeling that Whiz and its owners aren't much concerned about quality of life for those living nearby.  It's a once modern and small square building sitting at the corner of a large unkempt parking lot, with a lot of dirty windows, worn out picnic benches and broken counter stools just outside the dirty windows.  The menu is also from another time and yet it says what the owners feel like sharing about their dilapidated drive-in.

I parked in their parking lot and walked over to the front window and ordering counter and was panhandled by a pretty down and out toothless couple who looked they just finished a life ending attempt at copulation and failed.  A small group of students from nearby schools, a priest, a few scattered customers and some mean looking punks hung around the picnic tables our front and on the sides of the building, not very inviting but like I said, thei place ignores anything and everything outside the glassed in cube where they cook and count money.

I wanted to try a burger so I could share with you my experience and when I ask the counter person what their regular, best selling burger was, he mumbled incoherently 'da burger special' and since there were about half a dozen and he might have been in a coma, I just asked for a cheeseburger special with a diet coke and fries.  I sat on a broken stool at the outdoor counter and watched the inside and outside with amused skepticism, like waiting for a drug deal gone wrong to turn into a gun fight, but no such drama unfolded although it wouldn't have been out of character.  Soon enough the guy yelled at me, no names please, and handed me a brown bag and frail waxed paper cup and I arranged my find on the bag and took my first bite.  I'd ordered it as they serve it, no special request, and I got it and then got to wrestle with eating a grey, flavorless burger patty disguised with a runny, layo type dressing, shredded lettuce, chopped tomato, a lot of tasteless pickles on a bun that wasn't up to the job of holding it all together.

This type of burger can taste so good when drunk or hung over, but is a culinary nightmare when stone cold sober and hungry for just plain good food.  By the 2nd bite part of the bun lay on the ground along with much of the toppings and the melted cheese, no choices here, had coagulated into stone age toughness.  I was unable to finish it and focused for a flash on the recently frozen fries which were white as snow with the copious amount of salt shaken over them.  The diet coke was flat and the cup it came in was caving in from plain cheapness.  How does a place like this survive for so many years?  I don't really know, but one can speculate that the wild folks who hang around and pose like gangsters must buy a lot of burgers and fries or the nearby Church provides a subsidy to keep the kids out of their Church.  If the meat only looked like it had once been red.
author: Stu S.

description: havent been down here in ages .. { 1970s} need to get back down there again, used to go here while at my cousins on Capp St..
author: CATHY F.

description:
Homies:  Ey Ruca let's get our grub on over there.
Ruca aka me:  The Whiz?  Gross man.  It looks like a dump where cucarachas dance up on the hamburger bunz! 

*2 drinks later*

Ruca:  I'm hungry, fuck it, let's go to Whiz! 

First thing when we ordered: a water beetle was on the counter, and as we threw some cash at it,  waiting for it to dance, about 40 police cars + a Paddy Wagon  roll through, blockin off the whole area! 

 We heard a loud THUDD in the middle of the calle. Someone dropped a gun from the roof a church across the street. 
OOOOooooo CHIT! 

We looked up and some foo across the street , top of a church clinging to a saint,  basically caught. The cops gave him a ladder to come down but  homie put up a ten minute scene which consisted of him pushing the ladder away and joking  "Want me to jump?".  
The cops were pissed off going "Come down like a man" .  
Other cops were eating burritos, enjoying their break.   

NE Wayz, the joint was better than Medieval Times, lemme tell you, the food was great, but the entertainment was BETTER!
author: Roxane P.

description:
Everyone hears the name whiz BURGER, and they don't know that they make the second best cheese steak sandwich in the city... order the #4 (includes coke and fries)  with "hot peppers, grilled onions, and bell peppers" and you are good to go with a GREAT cheese steak.

Get the BURGER out of your head and go for the cheese steak.  I have never even had their burgers, and never will.  How could anybody eat a burger there after eating their cheese steak?  Closest to Philly besides Divisadero street a the Cheese Steak shop.
author: Timotheus C.

description:
Whiz is one of those places your dad took you to when you were a little kid.  It's no-nonsense; you order outside, wait outside, and eat your food outside.

The fries are good, and whatever vegetarian option I had was decent, although I don't remember what it was.  It's got its own parking lot, which is unusual for this part of the Mission.
author: John S.

description:
Dude fuck all y'all that diss the wonder of the Whiz.  Straight up.

First of all as a born and raised San Franciscan this place is OLD SCHOOL.  I remember going to the Whiz when I was little... back when the Mission was dangerous! Imagine that.

The fact of the matter is this: They don't care about you.  They don't care about your needs... unless those needs are a burger, crispy fried and the best fuckin' banana shake you ever laid your hands on.  To the cheap fuck who thought that the shakes are too much.  Been to St. Francis Fountain lately???  The banan shakes are better than that place by leaps and bounds.  They use FRESH bananas! So. Damn. Tasty.

On a trip to the Whiz the other day getting my haircut it went a little like this:

Counter Dude: What you want?
Me: Whiz Burger (the works), crispy fries, banana shake.
Counter Dude: Here? To go?
Me: Here.
Counter Dude: 5 minutes.
Me: Sweet
Counter Dude: Cool.

Done and done... no ass kissing, no "service"... it doesn't preport to be Park Chow nor DOES IT WANT TO BE!  The new peeps in San Francisco feel like every restaurant has to give them a blow job with their meal in order to get 5 stars.  That just isn't how it is.
author: Dutch G.

description:
Great turkey burger, awful fries. Is it that hard to blanch some fries in the morning, toss them in the freezer and then give them a 3 minute fry when they're ordered so they don't come out all soggy and oil-logged? If I can do it at home, Whiz Burger can do it. 

I will prob go back someday for another turkey burger or maybe a regular cheeseburger but I won't be ordering the fries.
author: Natalie G.

description:
!!!FRIBBLE ALERT!!!!

This review is of one thing only: The coffee milkshake. Mind you, I believe the Friendly's Fribble is technically a frappe, and of course a classic Fribble is served in the cold, cold steel canister in which is was mixed, which means it's enough to feed a family of four. This comes in a paper cup, but it's still the closest thing I've found on the West Coast to the only good thing on the menu at Friendly's. Sometimes you just want a Fribble, and this is the fix. What up New England!?!
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Damn good burgers, damn good shakes -- Watch your car like a maniac.

It is not worth the $400 we ended up paying as a result of eating there. My lady friend and I parked in their lot, got a burger and shake, ate it there, and then took a little walk. When we returned about 45 mins later, the car had been towed. The only signs were the standard "unauthorized vehicles will be towed/parking for customers only." The fellow at the counter told my now sobbing friend that, yeah, tow truck comes by every 15 minutes (???). 

I understand the need to protect your lot if you're in such a central location, but, Whiz Burger, be reasonable. Towing loving customers' cars is not a way to keep them coming back. Then again, if you split the fee with the tow company, I guess it's as if we'll be coming back for another 13 or so meals.
author: John F.

description:
I've driven past several times, but last week ate their for the first time.

It was late at night and the place was lit up like a beacon. I walked up and ordered at this counter and felt like I had walked back in time several decades.  The menu is simple.  The food is greasy. But somehow it does satisfy. It might have satisfied a bit more if I had been drunk. I think I will make sure of it next time.  

So I wouldn't come here for the burgers per se. I'd come here for the convenience --an easy walk for me--- and the atmosphere.  You know, old-time walk-up/drive-thru burger joint. It definitely scratches an occasional burger itch.
author: Padawan T.

description:
This is where Ponyboy and Dallas ate after killing the Socs.  
Cheap food.  Don't want cheap food?  Go somewhere else.  Don't expect this to be a gem.
author: Patrick A.

description: I gave 5 stars for the hot links. think it was the very first time i ate an authentic american thing
author: Pinqi F.

description: Wholehearted three (but not more) stars.  A stylish retro leftover serving... mediocre fast food.  It's convenient, it's cheap, and it tastes like food from an era of lower standards.  But Jesus is it good when you're drunk.
author: Eric S.

description: Its Saturday afternoon and the last day of the 2007 Bicycle Film Festival at the Victoria.  We're hungry and decide to take afew pedal strokes over to Whiz.  Hot link hot dog thingy and garlic fries quell my hunger.  Good food at a fair price.  Fortunately the weather was decent that day as  there is only outdoor seating.
author: andrew l.

description:
I gave Whiz Burger a extra star because the Bobby Teens made there "Hot City Boys" video there back in the 90s. Check out Whiz Burger in there now old video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ozThnDhiGmw 

The place is a Mission landmark, hopefully it won't go the way of the Chatterbox, the mural, and the giant sign. 

Good fast food in a old school happy days diner.
author: Johnny B.

description:
I've driven past Whiz many many times thinking ooh I must try that, it looks good.  It reminds me a little of Dick's in Seattle that has been a fixture on Broadway for many year, but this review isn't about them so apologies for the digression.

I had the Big Whiz burger minus the avocado.  I love avo but always find its inclusion on a burger a little odd.  The Big Whiz is obviously their signature dish and comprises of two patties, some sauce, lettuce, tomato, pickle and bacon served in a French roll and then expertly wrapped up in wax paper and sliced in two.  It was absolutely delicious, well seasoned and a great balance of flavours and I still think that the addition of avo would have been a bridge too far.  The use of a French roll rather than a burger bun is an inspired choice and sets the Big Whiz apart from your common garden variety burger.

The garlic fries we ordered to go with our meal were definitely garlic fries but woefully underseasoned and no salt was given to us in the bag.   I presume this was another misguided attempt to help keep my blood pressure low and if at any point in my future my doctor tells me it is anything other than textbook I'll thank the food service industry of California for doing its bit, but until then I'll keep on my high horse.

I did however think that Whiz was damned expensive for a counter service burger joint.  2 burgers and 1 portion of garlic fries came out at an eyewatering $18.  If we had added drinks each then we'd have been looking at $25.
author: Tony S.

description:
I have a friend who says "18th and South Van Ness...where you go to forget what happened to you at 17th and Capp." 

My girlfriend and I were having one of those next-morning, what-in-the-fuck-did-we-do-to-ourselves-last-night moments and decided the only way our shame and our hangovers could be squelched was via a very large, very greasy cheeseburger. 

Sure, the place looks a little sketchy, one of those places where you don't wanna interact with the clientele too much and where you probably shouldn't examine the kitchen too closely, but dear Lord, the place is fucking excellent. 

Not only do they have seriously old school burgers, fries, and shakes, but if you take your greasy brown bag of goodness and sit at one of their picnic tables--and by the time you get from the pickup window to one of the tables 10 feet away, your brown bag will be translucent from all of the grease--you will have a view while dining that is better than any channel on TV. As you munch on your salty, salty fries and chow on your burger with old school shredded lettuce and crinkle-cut pickle slices, you can watch a variety of pimps, crackhos, illiterates, and degenerates on parade. My girlfriend and I laughed so hard at the buffet of humanity that passed us by that we determined we might have been still drunk from the night before. 

Shit is cheap, shit is good, and the view is amazing. Get yer ass to The Whiz.
author: kdub ..

description:
Although my mild food snobbery rarely dissuades me from trying new places, this particular one had always scared me. I'd walked by it a zillion times on my way to and from Bart, and my preconceptions of it had been dark indeed: it stood as a postapocalyptic monument to the faraway days of Eisenhower and Khrushchev; unchanged and uncleaned in its half century, it quietly harkened to the utopian nostalgia of innocent teenagers at soda shops, while simultaneously failing to fend off accumulated decades of urban blight. This looked like the sort of dilapidated drive-in where gangbangers and homeless denizens would gather today, the sort of place that might have been the initially cheerful setting for a B-grade horror flick in the '80s, only to become the site of real shootings in the '90s, and which of course would carry roachy, ebola-laced Z-grade food that could kill on sight.

Thankfully, the reality was not such a faustian tapestry. The menu on the back wall is printed in Tomorrowland-esque retro futuristic style, and includes an assortment of burgers, dawgs, fries, shakes, and (disturbingly) chicken teriyaki. Past experience has taught me wariness of eating establishments that serve burgers, burritos, *and* teriyaki -- invariably none of them will be remotely edible -- but the lack of burritos in this case allowed Whiz past my radar with only a yellow alert.

Their impressive selection of fries included regular (thin-cut), garlic (didn't try because they were $3), and seasoned (the delicious waffle kind that are near impossible to find elsewhere). I paid the extra quarter for a dollop of mediocre Ranch to dip my seasoned fries. One of my lunch companions got an involuntarily supersized order of skinny fries for dessert, which seemed only fitting after her dinosaur-shaped and very probably not organic chicken nugget entre.

Shakes there were runny and unmemorable, offered in a variety of flavors which would have been divine had they contained any real ice cream. And in the espresso shake I ordered, real espresso. Funny how so many things in life could be improved with the simple addition of espresso. Heed the wisdom of this lesson at every opportunity, Grasshopper.

As for the burger, I got a 1/4 pound "junior" cheeseburger. It was probably the closest thing to a Tommy Burger I've had in Northern California: no ingredient is of particularly high quality, yet somehow the cheapness of it all coalesces into a product that surprisingly exceeds the sum of its parts. I'd still favor an In-n-Out or Nation's burger over a Whiz, but there's something transcendently gratifying about enjoying trashy food that logic dictates should be awful. This principle actually holds together many Midwestern delicacies: green bean casserole, cherry dump cake, and jello parfait among them.

The only thing about Whiz Burger that isn't stuck in the 1950s is the prices. I shelled out $9 for the junior burger, waffle fries, and shake. Ouchitude! Sometimes the painful reality of Bay Area prices can bust the illusion of an otherwise perfectly believable anachronism.

The quantity of grease consumed over lunch would have been better spread out over a month or two; my system was generally disgruntled following the experience. But my mouth had enough guilty pleasure that I may return occasionally. And no, I won't be trying the teriyaki.
author: Brian U.

description:
Three (and a half) stars.
The cheezburgers are pretty good and there's a lot on the menu to pick from for whatever combinations/styles of burger. I think that Mary's on 16th actually trumps them though, for  service & atmosphere. Of course, how many places in town ARE actually stroll-up joints? Take away half a point for their never seeming to catch the "HOLD the mustard" and for the prices on Shakes/Fries. They'll dink you for a Hamilton anyway they can.
That being said, a meal out of Whiz Burgers will forestall any other meal 
of an afternoon, easily- But they are (now) better than Flippers...
author: Mark L.

description:
Similar story to my Serrano's review.  Minus the unrequited love.  

Consistent, good, cheep, fast, close to home.  When I need a cheeseburger fix and I am lazy or short on time.  I go to Whiz Burger.  

I don't question the quality.  Things can be good and not of high quality.  Maybe that sounds bad, but whatever, there it is.  Do you love Count Chocula?  Boo Berry?  Wonka Candy?  Taco Bell?  I am sure those things are not make from top shelf materials.  I know for a fact that the ground meat used at Taco Bell is "Grade D" and there are oats added to it.  But I still love Mexi-melts.  

I had some friends eat here once and they claimed they had poopy-pants for the next 24 hours.  I love them, but they are a little delicate, intestinally speaking.  So if you have a cast-iron stomach and like cheesy burgers, this is a great place.
author: Michael C.

description:
I remember walking past this place on my walk from school home back in my elementary days, in fact, I met Steve Young there once, he was on location shooting a car commercial, the whiz sign was made look nice. That was then. 

I decided to throw this place into a few random nights and each time have been full, not impressed. I dont learn.
author: Joe J.

description: The Whiz Burger" is da BOMB.!!!! Don't judge the book by it's cover!! Yea ain't no top notch place, nothing impressive...it's been there for as  long as I can remember, love their "Whiz Burger" since I was a kid and still love it now!!!my kids also love it!!!  I've tried so many times to make them myself...and it jus NEVER comes out the way they do it!!!!! Try it before u knock it!! O Nd the shakes are good too... Mmm I gotta go soon!! Jus made myself hungry!!!
author: Jacqueline F.

description:
i was near the amc metreon theatre on fourth street.  my friend and i had a craving for chocolate malts.  i walked into mel's diner across the street and asked to see serving size of a malt and the price.  there was one size for to go orders.  i biked to whiz burgers and discovered they have THREE sizes:  regular, large and extra large.  the extra large cost less than the one, much smaller size container at mel's diner.  they put the containers in a carton and then in a plastic bag so i could get it in my backpack for the ride home. 
the price, product and service were excellent.  it was a very good value, quick delivery and a tasty malt!
author: Kevin E.

description:
I was running errands with a friend and we were both hungry. We wanted food fast, but not fast food, if you know what I mean. My friend remembered a burger she had at a bar in SOMA, but she didn't remember that the place wasn't open yet. All was almost lost until we came across Whiz Burgers. It's old school in that you order at the counter and eat outside on rough-hewn picnic tables. It's new school in that they have veggie burgers and mango shakes.

I had a Whiz Burger without avocado and a side of onion rings. The burger comes on a roll, which is a nice change. She had a cheeseburger with fries. She was very excited about the little brown bag containing her fries. I was excited about bacon because bacon makes a cheeseburger better. Her excitement faded during the meal. Perhaps her burger didn't live up to her standards. Perhaps the scent of the off-duty bike messengers at the nearby table put her off her appetite. (But bonus SF cred points for those scoring at home!) It's not my favorite burger in the City, and I'd probably give it 3.5 stars if I could, but if I was nearby, I'd return.
author: Timothy O.

description: I had the worst service i have ever had in my LIFE. I had bought a burger walked back to my job to eat it I have been there multiple times and never had the food bad or service bad at any time. When I got back to my desk and bite in the burger the most of the meat was still pink and i dont like eating pink meat at all. I called them  and the manager/boss/owner (Older Asian Male)  picked up the phone he was so rude when i told him that the meat was still pink he HUNG UP ON ME! I called him back and asked why did he hang up and he just hung up on me AGAIN! He did not believe me that the meat was not all the way cooked I walked back over there to show him the burger and he didn't even want to look at it. He kept yelling at me saying I'm causing problems when all i wanted was another burger not my money back. He kept yelling at me and saying that he has a lot of other customers and i wasn't important. He finally gave me a refund of my money for the burger WHICH I DID NOT WANT ALL I WANTED WAS ANOTHER BURGER!! The manager/boss/owner (Older Asian Male)  was very rude the whole time and he did not beleive me and he stated I was causing him problems. (HOW AM I CAUSING PROBLEMS WHEN ALL I WANTED WAS ANOTHER BURGER) I am NEVER GOING BACK TO WHIZ BURGERS. THE WORST SERVICE I HAD FROM HIM MOST DEFINITELY LOST AN CUSTOMER.
author: Mondale E.

description:
Whiz Burger is one of those places that you remember seeing in like the 1950s.. ok, maybe I wasn't alive in the 1950s but you know what I mean.. 

The old, beat up, bird guano stained half broken sign proudly marks the corner of 18th and South Van Ness.  There's no indoor seating at this burger stand, so you'll have to take your food home, or eat on the oddly proportioned picnic tables that look like they were recycled from the construction site down the street.  Well, at least they're recycled.

As for the food, it's what you'd expect from a burger stand.  Fast, hot, greasy and tasty.  I prefer the burger burger myself -- it's just your classic hamburger on a sesame seed bun.  The "whiz burger" is a strange sandwich on a french roll with avocado and bacon.  I like my burger.. um.. more burger like.

The shakes are delish.. i always go for the chocolate banana...  Anyway, stop by whiz on your way to wherever.. it was one of those places that I'd always pass by and think to myself.. "Hmmm.. I should stop there".  And one day I did.  and I was happy.
author: Dennis Y.

description: They have a printout that says "Best place for feeling like you are on a road trip". That pretty sums it up. This is road food for wanderers looking for Dolores Park.
author: Gonzalo M.

description:
Sitting outside on the picnic tables (no indoor dining) is not bad on a nice day.

The service and food are no-nonsense.

Whiz Burger is served on a hoagie roll. The meat patty is coarsely ground. You do not have an option for medium well, etc., so you may infer whatever you want to infer from that fact (e.g., unlikely to be Niman Ranch beef).

For the money ($9 for whiz burger, fries, and bottled water), I'd walk the extra few blocks to Burger Joint.
author: Rob T.

description:
It comes down to this - if your expectations are realistic, then you'll like this place.

I wouldn't say that the food is "good" but that's not the point. If you want the perfect veggie burger or a place to take your parents, then go somewhere else. If you want to eat nasty greasy fries while gazing upon some of SF's meaner streets, then this fits the bill.

And who doesn't want that from time to time?
author: Josh K.

description:
As I stand in my kitchen and decide not to eat another pack of ramen, I look out the window, and she calls for me "Cheese burger with sauteed mushrooms." I dont bother with the fries, sometimes go for a shake, onion rings are as bad as the fries, but I dont want fries with that, give me my burger!

Cheesesteak is good if you are looking for a portion control medium size sandwich.
author: Willie K.

description:
I've been searching for a good "side of the road" burger stand here in the city...not the "gourmet trying to be more than a burger burger". So when I saw Whiz, I got all excited that maybe I'll get a sloppy burger wrapped in shiny foil with shredded lettuce, pickles and special burger sauce. Unfortunately, this wasn't the place. Though the burger wasn't bad (a little on the dry side), it was far from a burger stand burger. And the price was a little high for a burger stand too. I'll have to say that the shakes were pretty good. 

I guess when a burger place also serves chicken teryaki, you take a gamble.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Frozen in the 80s blue-collar era of this city now all but disappeared, this place is no nonsense and the real deal.  As I type this review my keyboard is starting to glisten with the glow of french fry grease and twinkling salt.  

Order the junior burger with extra pickles, ketchup and mustard only.  Accompany that with a small order of  fries.  Sit outside at the bar and hum "God Bless America" as you gorge yourself.  

PS - I ordered this today for lunch and my total came to $6.66.
author: marc d.

description:
So I decided that on my way home through the Mission I would make like a tourist and pay a visit to Whiz Burgers. I've passed by here so many times... and thought - man this is just a good ole slice of Americana... it's like that famous film with Richard Dreyfus and almost on my doorstep. 

So I ordered me a good old fashioned veggie burger, garlic fries (I have spent nearly 2 years in this country and not yet sampled garlic fries - I decided my cherry had to pop eventually on that delicious note) and a malted chocolate ice cream milkshake. 

Verdict? Well, the veggie burger was your average veggie burger and tasted like one too. The garlic fries, soggy and unsalted. The milkshake - tasted like it had banana in it. I am allergic to bananas by the way, so that is definitely not a route to my heart. I've also spent half the evening in discomfort and I can't decide from what part of my meal tonight. 

Overall - I am not a burger fan by any stretch of the mind. So it would take a miracle to wow me. For something quirky in the middle of a town center, Whiz burgers is fun as a novelty and a little randomness in a town full of such things. Worth going.. possibly after a few beers on a hot summer night.
author: Catriona C.

description:
Oh it's good.. trust me. My first time here was when the crack heads next door to my building pulled the fire alarm - I decided to whiz on to Whiz Burger with my friends instead of waiting outside for no reason.  

Since then, I've had the turkey burger and veggie burger ... all great!  I have a weakness for french fries so I never go without.  Their regular fries are a good intermediate between skinny fries and fat fries.  They also make seasoned cris-cut fries which are awesome.  

Always nice to take it togo with some beers and head to Dolores Park if you're tired of eating burritos in the Mission.  They also open late 9:45-10pm everyday.  Score!
author: Christina C.

description:
Good amount of fixins which is key to any good burger. They give you a mound of lettuce, tomato, and pickles. The only thing that bummed me out was that they put mayo on their burgers. Yuck. 
The turkey burger was tasty albeit a bit dry and my buddy's mushroom burger was delectable....just a guess but she demolished it. I'd recommend the seasoned waffle fries...just like the cafeteria lady used to make em...crisp on the outside and soft on the inside...the way a perfect fry should be. 
Tip: Take it to go as bums tend to pester you while you are busy stuffing your face on the picnic benches outside.
author: Stacy T.

description:
I had no idea...

I walk by this place nearly every day to get to work and didn't really turn my nose up at it (goodness knows I'm not dive snob) but just never factored it in as a place to eat.

But holy moly -- that's a pretty decent burger.  Like a good diner burger.  And as most have said, it's definitely the best in the neighborhood.

Yelp encouraged me to go check it out and to that I say thank you, Yelp.
author: Johanna w.

description: I just wish that someone would take this place over and make the food edible.  Okay, it's edible, but just barely.  And I've tried it more than once because it is sooo stuck in time that I am drawn in, thinking "Really, how bad could a burger and fries be?"  Pretty bad apparently.  I will not be going back again until there is a big banner reading "Under New Ownership"
author: sarah b.

description:
Ok seriously, the banana shakes here are amazing, and I'm a banana shake snob.  They use fresh bananas, which is the only proper way to do it!  YUM, YUM, YUM!

That's the only thing I can give it 5 stars for, as that's all I ever order there. .  .
author: Jenn K.

description:
Oh yes, I was starving today between lunch and dinner. How starving? I was running errands and had the urge to gnaw my own foot off. Luckily I drove th Whiz. The place looks like something from the past and I rolled up for a jr. burger and a strawberry shake. 

The burger reminded me of one I had as a kid, so I am pleased. The shake was just OK, but I'll be back for the burgers and the fries I saw other customers chowing down on. Maybe I'll try the chocolate or the mango shake.

Plus, how can ya hate a place with chili dogs?
author: Akasha A.

description:
I used to live literally 5 minutes away from this place, walking distance! 
so old school!! i love it... the food is also very good!
author: Monique S.

description:
I always get what I know taste good and stick to that. At places like Whiz, you stray and you might end up paying the price. This place definitely has a tasty Turkey burger. I've had nothing else but I hear the tuna-melt is equally delicious? I've had a friend order the grilled cheese once, its basically a few slices of cheese and bread nuked...did not look appealing or even editable. 

I wouldn't recommend sitting down on the benches to eat your meal unless you like to be accosted by crackheads. Whiz is definitely "the" place if you need a quick burger fix on the way to somewhere else. It's a mom-pop burger joint and it delivers for what it is.
author: Richard K.

description:
I love how these old burger stands are still around. They stand tall and might not reach the height of the golden arches but I take them over their ubiquitous counterparts. I like the one down the way from the stork in oakland also, but I like the burgers here better.

I had the turkey burger ($4.53) and found that it made my gut very happy. Fries, however are standard fare. I especially like the signage that hangs over the place.
author: wayne s.

description: One of the longest-lasting greasy spoon drive-thru establishments in the Mission area. Great shakes, hamburgers, and fries... and a local clientele that proves that it has worth. If you become a regular customer, you'll meet all sorts of "mission rats" who frequent this place, and every one of them will have great stories to entertain you before they hit you p for change.
author: Sam A.

description: On my way to one my favorite bars (see "Truck" review), I didn't think it was wise to have "x" amount of cocktails without eating.  I came upon "Whiz" burgers:  I looked at the menu and the price was right, the service was quick and the burger with all the fixings, filled me up nicely.
author: Carlos C.

description:
I have lived here for almost 2yrs now, and this place caught my eye the 1st week I was in SF... and I had never been there until yesterday!

This place is so freaking good, it actually rivals my out-of-state affection for In&Out Burger.  I had a Whiz Burger w/out bacon, seasoned Waffle Fries with some amazing ranch on the side, and a tastetastic Banana Shake ---   

Everything was just right & exactly what I needed at 9:30pm... toasted bun, fresh lettuce/tomato, and WAFFLE FRIES. I do love the animal meat, and this place serves it up real good.   If you haven't been here, do it now.  I mean, right now.

(Fear not Veggies, they do have Veggie Burgers also.)
author: Jake B.

description:
Solid burgers, cool retro vibe. Deduct one star for something in my partner's burger that was bad, and another star for simply not kicking ass. No stars deducted or added for the loose bar stool that, while probably being a safety hazard, was actually quite good fun.

Seasoned fries = must order.
author: Neil S.

description:
Exactly what I was hoping for.  Awesome burger, lots o fixins, melty cheese, toasted bun, squashed down and melded into one solid slab of deliciousness.  

Minus one star because the fries were undercooked & kinda soggy, and the cheap-o brand ketchup packets were annoying.
author: Philip K.

description: I will admit first, I've had ocassions where my veggie burger was overcooked, but that was only one time. Every other time i've come here., the fries are perfect and so is my veggie burger!
author: Natalie M.

description: I think I have just consumed the greatest fresh banana shake ever, accompanied by a pretty good veggie burger (with cheddar) and crosscut fries. Fourth star for the shake, for sure.
author: Maximillian M.

description: A very tasty burger. Makes me wish I was around when such drive-in style burger shops were common place. Awesome milkshakes as well.
author: Jonathan F.

description: Whiz was something of a dinner staple of mine when I lived closer to this place.  Some might say it appears grungy, and you must sit outside (or take your food elsewhere), but it's also got ample parking and a unique building that gives it character.  Their fare is classic American diner food, and it doesn't disappoint, for the price especially.  If you just get a craving for grilled meat in a bun like I do from time to time, definitely check out THE whiz burger--two patties in a French roll, with avocado and bacon, for $6.75, little more with cheese.  Their shakes are also money.
author: Alan R.

description: I like the place. The burgers are pretty much standard fast food /burger stand fair (frozen patties) but they are tasty and better than a fast food chain. On the other hand, its fun to go here and the fries are tasty.
author: Stephen W.

description: Eaten here a few times, never had a bad experience. Lots of picnic tables setup outside to eat at. The burger & fries were tasty. My girlfriend loves the ability to order Tang as an alternative to soda :)
author: illy m.

description:
Whiz Burger is a great walk-up burger joint in the Mission.  I spied it while driving up S. Van Ness and made a mental note to visit on a weekend when a greasy burger is the preferred remedy for a hangover.

As to be expected, that day came sooner than later, and I found myself ordering a cheeseburger, Whiz Burger, waffle fries, and a hot dog.  Yeah, so what...I was hung over and grease does a body good (sometimes).  

These burgers harkened back to the good ol' days:  when guys put the same oil in their hair that they did in their V-8s.  Thick with nostalgia and calories, if Whiz Burger doesn't fix you up when you're feeling down for some comfort food...then I doubt anything will.  

This place isn't tidy and doesn't want to be either.  Sun beaten posters and food advertisements are taped everywhere you look, but the service is prompt.  You may have to share a table with a pigeon or two, but if you can find an outdoor greasy spoon without that kind of clientele, let me know.  

Great food for someone who had an, ahem, great weekend!
author: Mark M.

description: I am constantly amazed as to how this old drive in has survived. Every time i pass it its like looking into the past. Now let me say that if your looking for the worlds best burger or some other culinary wonder its not here. However you do get a good cheap burger and fries at a great price. Also they have great milkshakes. Besides the food, its a cool place to look at.
author: paul a.

description: The food may be ok to mediocre but the owners (father and son) are miserable and nasty people.  See multiple reviews on the towing of customers from their lot. Save your money for better food and kinder people.
author: Emily G.

description: Best banana shake ever AND they take debit cards when it seems like many places are moving to cash only.
author: Matt L.

description:
This place reminds me of Beep's Burgers, but run by Mexicans. In my hood, so it's immediately a win.

Yet another place I wish I could eat everyday and die happy.
author: Alexis C.

description: I had a hot dog here once. It came cut lengthwise with pickles and tomato. They might as well have  put sprouts on that shit. The burger's were pretty worthless as well. There's a lot on the menu so maybe there's a winner up there but I'm done trying to find it. Whiz gets half a star for milkshakes and a half  a star for that pang of nostalgia it evokes in a small town boys heart.
author: Mingus R.

description: Wildwood tofu burgers as the standard veggie burger is an A+ choice.  The "Seasoned Fries" are waffle fries, the normal fries are thick, and the garlic fries are better left un-ordered.  I very much enjoy Whiz Burger and would subscribe to their newsletter.
author: Joshua S.

description: I have always been tempted to stop and try the Italian burrito. What could an Italian burrito possibly consist of? I'm completely baffled.
author: Steven C.

description: I love Whiz Burger. Do not come here for gourmet. Come here because the burgers are solid, the fries are crisp, and the urge commands. They even have a parking lot, so bring your disastrous carbon footprint.
author: Allison L.

description: Good in that ... bad sort of way. Try the waffle fries!
author: Maria D.

description: I really like Diet Coke. Especially when it's $1.39 for a cup that's billed as small but is really medium and is served with lots of ice. Therefore, I really like Whiz Burgers.
author: Mairead J.

description: I love Whiz Burger. The vegie burgers are good especially with grilled onions. The fries and onion rings are usually good although occasionally they overcook them, but that doesn't happen often. They always get my order correct, which I truly appreciate. And they have a parking lot. What's not to love?
author: Wan T.

description: Good greasy food.  If you love your arteries then stay away from the Philly Cheesesteak.
author: Sas C.

description: This place may not look like much on the outside but it's still a treasure. Great food and fast too. I always enjoy going over there to grab a quick burger and shake or soda. The employees are friendly and willing to explain what goes on each type of burger. One of these days I'm going to have to try their veggie burger.
author: Todd H.

description:
our neighbor sherman used to own whiz burger until he died in the early 90s.  the first time i ever saw this place was maybe around 1987 when my dad left me in the car on 18th st. to go do something shady im sure.

the key things that differentiate a whiz burger are the long soft-roll like bun, and automatic bacon and avacado.  whiz burger i would classify as a 2nd tier chinese hamburger, i dont normally compare chinese hamburgers in the same class of food-item as regular hamburgers such as 1st tier burgers like pearls burgers and joe's cable car or 2nd tier burgers like zeitgeist, barneys and big mouth burgers.
author: christopher a.

description:
personally, i think whiz burger has the best veggie burger in the city.  it comes with all the fixin's and it's a wildwood tofu burger which is the cream of the crop as far as veggie burgers are concerned.  they put lots of pickles on your veggie burger which i like and it's best with cheese and avocado.  one thing is that they don't put ketchup on your burger, you have to add that yourself. and, if you get it to go on a regular basis you'll end up with a drawer full of ketchup packets.

you have to get a shake if you go!  they're all good but the fresh banana shake is the best.

i would give whiz 5 stars but sometimes their french fries are less than stellar.  usually i think they are good and crispy but every now and then i get a bad batch.
author: Kristie P.

description:
yum! the veggie burger is surprisingly filling and delicious. 
they have a lot of drink choices and really greasy fries. 
watch out for the crackheads around the corner.
author: Oleya P.

description: The Whiz Burger (burger with lots of mayo, bacon, avocado, and other forms of animal and vegetable fat) is served on a french roll.  It's retardedly delicious.
author: Michael M.

description: I like to issue fatwa's with Shaketada al Fryphy at the Church of Whizzlam.  Screw 40 virgins, just give me a banana shake and a whiz burger with a small order of fries.
author: Mark P.

description: I sat on the bench eating my veggie Burger thinking I was in Fullerton and not on s. van ness street . burger was great and way more interesting than boca or garden variety that EVERYONE uses which is very very boring! The criss-cut/waffle fries  were great and greezy and the root beer fuzzy like I like it- great 2pm breakfast  on a sat.
author: A. Gun n.

description: Ahhh Whiz Burger, definitely a destination spot for my wife and I on a Sunday afernoon. My wife gets the whiz Burger and I always opt for the veggie burger with fries. You hear the term "old school" over and over when people describe this place. I'll agree, the ambiance and old -never refurbished chairs and counter tops give you the old school feel, but its more like a run down memory of the way things used to be. I like the food but I think the name WHIZ burger is very appropriate as we almost always smell urine while we are eating. Its fun to go on a Sunday afternoon because the church across the street lets out around 1pm and you can spot some really awful church outfits. You have to love a church with a hotdog vendor outside! All in all, Whizburger is a great place to soak up Saturday nights hangover and move on quickly before the smell of piss ruins your appetite.
author: Go Cat Go G.

description: Pretty damn pricey for a grease shack.
author: Paul W.

description: it's another "WTF? I haven't reviewed Whiz Burgers?! How could that be?" After all, the irresistible Whiz Burger (served on a french roll, with bacon AND avocado and the usual burger makings, then neatly wrapped and cut in half even though gluttons like me will just consume the whole thing in one sitting). the cross cut fries are crispety crunchety good, so are the shake offerings (hmmmmm... mango shake) AND they have corn dogs. There was a time that I craved WB but got dissuaded by my friends and went to a vegan place instead. THAT was a mistake. I was depressed for days, only to be cured by the tasty goodness housed on the corner that WB occupies.
author: ray e.

description:
whiz burger is a decent if i'm looking for a cheap lunch place to satify that carving for a burger or hot link with fries & washing it down with a shake.  the burgers are overall decent nothing to majorly rave about.  the hot link sandwich is pretty good, sliced in half down the middle served on a seeded roll with the standard fixins.  the fries are pretty good when they are hot.  the milk shakes are the best though.

not a bad place to pick up a quick bite to eat or just craving greasy spoon burger.  the prices are pretty reasonable for what you are getting.  parking is available either on the street on in their parking lot.  they only accept cash.
author: larry s.

description:
i love shredded lettuce.
this place has it.
don't sit at the tables. this should seem obvious as they are a free for all to anyone on s. van ness and 17th.. but hey, whatever.

**i'm a veg so it's all i've had there and it's good.
author: A S.

description: The veggie burgers are vegan, so long as you specify NO MAYO (they use the Wildwood burgers, which are my favorite), and they use the delicious pickles, the sour ones, not the weird sweet ones. The garlic fries, I'm told, are made without butter, and are also vegan and slathered in a ridiculously amazing amount of garlic. They are also *crispy* on the outside just the way I like them. The only complaint I have is that the fries get cold kind of quickly.
author: Katie R.

description:
Really good shake, mediocre burger. Great if you want to get full & eat outside; bad if you want a really good burger.

Have to say, I was disappointed. My burger was dry and took about 10 minutes to make without anybody in line. All the parts seemed fresh & freshly made, but they never came together. For the price & the wait, I should be getting something better than what I can find at a carnival.

I was hoping for a mission version of Berkeley's smokehouse or Sam's on broadway.
author: Floyd L.

description: This place is hella good. And if you don't like it, you can just get the hell out.
author: Judy C.

description:
the cross-cut fries are yummy here, as are the shakes (last time i was there, i had them make me a banana-chocolate mix).  

the veggie burgers are just so-so, though.  

this place is fine for a quickie grease-fest, but definitely not the best.
author: Elle B.

description: Great turkey burgers and fries.  And that seems to be the only thing I ever order, so I can't really speak for the other 50 things on the menu.
author: Antichris E.

description: A co-worker of mine recommended this place last week, so I walked there from work on Friday to check it out. I had a hot dog and a banana shake. The hot dog was par for a hot dog, but the banana shake was killer! I might have go go back for another one of those sometime soon... YUMMMMMMMYYYYYYYYYYYY!!!
author: Lindsey S.

description: Since this place is a hop and a skip from my condo, i had to try it. My roommate told me to not to try it since its in the mission district and on the corner where all the crazy people hang late at night. That didn't stop me from trying the place out and i'm happy i did! OMG they have Garlic fries! Not the powder mixture but real garlic and parsley garlic fries. My love for garlic fries is beyond anything, anywhere they sell garlic fries I'm there! Their burgers are good as hell, its not your regular shaped burgers but I don't expect everything to be normal in the mission. The Whiz Burger is my absolute favorite, why? It has bacon and avocado without paying the extra price to add them on. Their quick, sometimes friendly and that's why you'll see me here grabing a bite to eat.
author: Lucky M.

description: Chicken melt was average and the fries were average but I love the ambiance of a real outdoor diner.  I'm yet to try a real chicken sandwich or burger.  I'll come back.
author: Ankur P.

description: This place is great! The burgers are tasty! Shakes are great also. I've never had a negative experience there.
author: J M.

description:
the memories will bring me back there when i find myself in the mission again.  we started walking by and just picking up fries (they were good) till we decided we were ready to venture into their other food.  the veggie burgers are good especially with avocado!  you can eat on the bar with stools spaced too far apart to sit close enough to your sweetie.  we parked and ate in a u-haul once and watched a guy pour a bucket of lard into a hole in the ground in the parking lot.
go for the experience and partly for the food.
author: Monk R.

description: Food is solid. the milkshakes are yum. it's fun to get food and sit outside on a nice day.
author: Veena S.

description:
don't be afraid - it's actually clean in there. i promise.

the burger was solid. my copilot said it was indeed a very good veggie burger. the seasoned waffle-cut fries were yum. and the banana shake is TO DIE FOR.

better burger than burgermeister, though i did like slider's better.
author: Clover Dan ..

description: I call my orders in, and then pick them up. They have on site parking, which is rare and awesome. I love their veggie burger with avocado- it's probably deep fried or something, because it's so much better than the one i make at home.  Their fries are amazing, I crave them on a regular basis, as do the people I work with- it's pretty much a weeky thing. Reasonably priced, quick and convenient.
author: Megan C.

description: Yum.  Damn fine burgers, fries and shakes.  Not the best in SF, but the best in the neighborhood with a gigantic 60's-era signage.
author: Kimbro B.

description: love this place! they saved my horrible hangover from that damn love holiday with the best cheeseburger I have ever had. The bun was a little toasty and the toppings delicious!
author: Susan M.

description: The Whiz... Best drive-up 50's style burger joint in the city!  They have a unique veggie burger, but I always go for the Whiz Burger, criss-cut fries, and a root beer freeze (it's like a root beer milkshake).  Being at 18th and SVN don't be alarmed if you find yourself amongst crackheads, junkies, and hookers.
author: Josiah B.

description: I've heard a lot of rumors as to the vegan or non veganess of this place but ill trust Josh on this one.  If you've got a hangover or just a hankering and the only cure is greasy american fast food, this place will do you right.  Once I saw Tragedy eat here.
author: Britton R.

description: I didn't care much for the burgers, but MMMMM fantastic strawberry shakes and criss-cut fries so close to home. It doesn't get much better...
author: Natalia P.

description:
so, basically 95% of my friends live within a 10-block radius of whiz burger, while i live in the cuts of the richmond, so i spend a lot of time driving back and forth across the city, making eating sometimes precarious...

but wait! have no fear, whiz burger to the rescue! seeing that it was still open and i hadn't eaten in a while (making me cranky like woah), i pulled into their parking lot (yay! not everyone is a hipster on a bike!) and was thrilled to see that they had chicken, turkey and veggie burgers all as menu items! i have not eaten red meat since i was a kid, and i don't plan to start anytime soon, so this was a good bonus. and their fries are so yum! i had them in my car when i picked up a friend, and we both could not stop eating them. they are well-seasoned and just crispy enough to not be gross and soggy. i also had a turkey burger which was a little over-cooked but still good and really this is a totally legit quick-bite.

and having had their fries, i'm really grateful i don't live closer...
author: Elizabeth O.

description: the veggie burger was squishy & fell apart. requesting mushrooms on top took a little too long to explain. way overpriced. sigh.
author: Jade P.

description: i'm a sucker for drive in's, but whiz burgers is nowhere in the same category as beeps out in ingleside.
author: Pickle R.

description: the best banana milkshake i've experienced.
author: hilary w.

description: The best veggie burger in the whole world! I am not kidding.  I wish there were more whiz burgers all across the world.
author: Jessie H.

description: best burger I've ever had. Meat is not the best quality but it is a PERFECTLY constructed burger, every time. What else is there to say? 5 stars.
author: blimp w.

description: Great Burgers, waffle fries and last but not least the banana shakes. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Patty G.

description: the place has burgers, fries, grilled cheese sammitches and friggin TERIYAKI bowls c'mon people what more do you want when it's late night and you fell off the wagon in the Mission ha
author: Lolo G.

description: Mmm. the veggie burgers are so good because they are deep fried in the same oil as the meat. They are also made of tofu instead of oats and crap. Also, the thin McDonalds-type fries are tasty. It's kind of expensive, though, for a place that serves fries in a paper bag, but hey, free parking!
author: Cathy S.

description: got a sandwich of some kind here and took this little video of one of my favorite signs in the city.  how can you not love Whiz Burger. old school all the way.  the guy was nice and didn't catch me doing the video...
author: Veronica V.

description: The milkshakes rock! And they are cheaper here than at the diners around town.  I may develop a habit, and a spare tire made of milkshakes.
author: C G.
